column1: Kaisariani (Greek: Καισαριανή) is a suburb and a municipality in the eastern part of the Athens agglomeration in Greece.
Kaisariani is located about 3 km (1.9 mi) southeast of Athens city centre
column2: and 3 km (1.9 mi) of the Acropolis of Athens. The municipality has an area of 7.841 km2. Towards the east the municipality extends to the forested Hymettus mountain
column3: where the 11th century Kaisariani Monastery is situated. The built-up area of Kaisariani is continuous with that of Athens and the suburb Vyronas to the southwest. The main thoroughfare is Ethnikis Antistasis Avenue
column4: which connects Kaisariani with central Athens and the eastern beltway Motorway 64.

column1: The town was founded in 1922 as a refugee camp for refugees driven from Asia Minor
column2: most of whom coming from Smyrna.

column1: Formerly part of the city of Athens
column2: Kaisariani was created as a municipality in 1933. The name was derived from Caesarea
column3: the historical capital city of Cappadocia

column1: The Kaisariani rifle range is notable as the site of the execution of 200 communists on 1 May 1944 by the Nazi occupiers as a revenge for the death of German general Franz Krech
column2: who had been killed in a guerrilla ambush near Molaoi a few days before.
